15.text:
The National Gallery is world-famous for its
collection of western European art, but when

20.text:
we wander round the galleries, do we stop
to consider why the pictures we see were acquired;

27.text:
how they got to Trafalgar Square; why they
are displayed in the way they are; or how

32.text:
they came to receive their attributions to
particular artists?

37.text:
Such questions are certainly worth a moment’s
thought for their answers open up central

42.text:
aspects of the life and function of the National
Gallery, and reveal just how much we owe to

48.text:
one individual, who transformed the fortunes
of this institution.

54.text:
The person in question is Sir Charles Eastlake,
who was the National Gallery’s first Director

62.text:
Born in 1793 in Plymouth, he had ambitions
to become a great painter. Having trained

69.text:
in London at the Royal Academy Schools, at
that time in the wing adjacent to the National

75.text:
Gallery, he went to Rome in 1816 where he
ended up staying for the next 14 years. Eastlake

84.text:
travelled widely in Europe, especially in
Italy, acquiring a detailed knowledge of western

90.text:
European art and mixing with some of the leading
European painters and thinkers about art.

98.text:
He also began to acquire a reputation as a
significant painter. His early bandit scenes

107.text:
helped to make his name, while his later religious
works were esteemed at the end of his career.

113.text:
But Eastlake’s art could not compare, for
instance, with the work of his friends the

119.text:
portrait painter Sir Thomas Lawrence and the
landscape artist Turner. Ultimately, Eastlake’s

126.text:
reputation as a painter, though good, was
never stellar.

129.text:
Scholarly and meticulous, with a good organisational
sense, Eastlake, on his return to London in

139.text:
1830, soon came to the notice of those interested
in promoting the arts in the public sphere,

145.text:
including the politician Sir Robert Peel and
also Prince Albert. Consequently, in 1841

153.text:
Eastlake became Secretary of the Fine Arts
Commission, with responsibility for finding

158.text:
artists to paint murals to decorate the new
Houses of Parliament.

163.text:
With his reputation ever rising, Eastlake
was appointed President of the Royal Academy

169.text:
in 1850 and five years later, in 1855, he
became the National Gallery’s first Director,

175.text:
at which point he abandoned his career as
a painter. At the National Gallery, Eastlake

182.text:
concentrated his efforts on filling the gaps
in the collection, because he wished to see

187.text:
it become fully representative of the story
of western European art.

192.text:
Initially he focused his efforts on acquiring
early Italian pictures. To this end, and with

200.text:
an annual picture-purchasing grant of £10,000,
he spent each summer abroad.

206.text:
He often travelled with his feisty wife, the
writer and art-critic, Lady Elizabeth, his

211.text:
manservant Nicholas Tucker, and the Gallery’s
Travelling Agent, Otto Mundler. His journeys

218.text:
involved much discomfort: after all damp,
flea-ridden beds, unpalatable food, and long,

225.text:
jolting carriage journeys were par for the
course in the mid-19th century.

229.text:
Eastlake kept a series of Travel Notebooks
in which he recorded the places visited and

236.text:
the pictures seen. He constantly put his mind
to matters of authentication, using novel

243.text:
methods of research into artists’ techniques
to assist him. His negotiations involved him

250.text:
in persuading hesitant owners or wily dealers
to part with pictures at reasonable prices.

257.text:
The record speaks for itself: in a single
decade Eastlake acquired over 150 pictures

264.text:
Once the pictures had reached London, Eastlake
ensured they were well displayed. Bearing

271.text:
in mind new trends in European museums, he
no longer showed the pictures as they had

277.text:
been at the National Gallery’s first home,
100 Pall Mall, in random order, densely arranged,

286.text:
Instead, from 1856 for the very first time,
core information was supplied via an early

294.text:
form of labelling, and detailed, scholarly
catalogues were also published. To allow individual

304.text:
schools of art to be enjoyed on their own
merits, Eastlake started to hang pictures

308.text:
by their country of origin and in chronological
order, and he thought too about how pictures

314.text:
should be framed and lit and against what
colour background they should be displayed.

320.text:
Perhaps surprisingly, this slight, frail and
grave man was the formative influence in the

327.text:
creation of the modern National Gallery. Yet
as a painter, scholar, and ultimately connoisseur,

334.text:
Eastlake’s many-sidedness contributed to
the greatness of his achievement. His legacy

341.text:
is most visible in the pictures on display,
but his thinking about art and how it should

347.text:
be displayed should not be forgotten for it
foreshadowed in important ways the work the

353.text:
Gallery undertakes today to care for and promote
interest in its pictures.
